column26: Newer CSS features can improve performance. One notable example is content-visibility: auto. This property allows the browser to skip rendering work for off-screen content until it is needed. Using content-visibility: auto on containers far down the page can significantly boost render performance by deferring work for content not yet visible. This means faster initial load and better interaction timing (INP) because the browser isnâ€™t busy painting things the user canâ€™t see yet. Use it for large lists or sections that start off-screen â€“ youâ€™ll reduce memory usage and speed up the parts that matter most to the user.

column26:
Current Polling Pattern:

await asyncio.sleep(interval) # Polls every 5 seconds Issues:

Wastes resources when queue is empty Fixed interval regardless of load Multiple workers may cause database contention Better Approaches:

Cloud Pub/Sub: Push-based, event-driven Cloud Tasks: Managed queue with retry Adaptive polling: Increase interval when idle

h1. Gemini API calls have no rate limiting

extraction_result = await extract_items_from_media(whatsapp_data) Issues:

No rate limiting for Gemini API Could hit quota limits and fail No backoff strategy No cost monitoring Solutions:

Implement exponential backoff Add rate limiter (e.g., aiolimiter) Monitor API usage in Cloud Monitoring Set budget alerts in GCP


Problem Description
The Gemini API integration lacks proactive protection:

# No Request Rate Limiting - Nothing prevents hitting quota
# No Circuit Breaker - Keeps trying even if Gemini is down
# No Timeout - Hung API calls block workers indefinitely
# No Fallback - All orders fail if Gemini unavailable

except KeyboardInterrupt: print(f"\nðŸ›‘ Worker {self.worker_id} stopping...") self.running = False Issues:

Doesn't wait for current job to finish May leave items in "processing" state forever No cleanup of database locks Fix Needed:

async def shutdown(self): self.running = False if self.current_task: await self.current_task # Wait for completion

h1. Update any stuck "processing" items back to "pending"

if whatsapp_data.retry_count >= 3: whatsapp_data.status = 'failed'

h1. Then what? Data is stuck forever

Issues:

Failed items have no recovery path No manual retry mechanism No notification on permanent failures No investigation tools Solutions:

Add a dead letter table/queue Implement admin API to retry failed items Send alerts via Cloud Pub/Sub or email Add forensic logging for failed items

print(f"âŒ Error processing WhatsApp ID {whatsapp_data.id}: {e}") Issues:

No structured logging No log aggregation No alerting on failures Hard to debug in production Fix Needed:

import logging import structlog

logger = structlog.get_logger() logger.error("processing_failed", whatsapp_id=whatsapp_data.id, error=str(e), retry_count=whatsapp_data.retry_count )

logging_config.py - Core logging configuration with:

structlog for structured logging
Rich console output for dev (colorized, readable)
JSON output for prod (GCP Cloud Logging compatible with severity field)
Auto-detection of environment via K_SERVICE env var (Cloud Run sets this)
Correlation ID context tracking
Performance metrics decorator
*middleware.py - FastAPI middleware for:*

Auto-generating/extracting correlation IDs from X-Correlation-ID header
Request/response logging with duration metrics
Slow request detection (>1s threshold)
*Updated files (logging only, no logic changes):*

main.py - Added middleware and startup/shutdown logging
worker.py - Replaced prints with structured logs
routers/whatsapp.py - Replaced prints

column26:
engine = create_async_engine(DATABASE_URL, echo=True) Issues:

No connection pool limits defined echo=True in production (performance hit) No connection timeout settings No retry logic for connection failures Fix Needed:

engine = create_async_engine( DATABASE_URL, echo=False, # Disable in production pool_size=10, # Max connections per worker max_overflow=20, pool_pre_ping=True, # Verify connections pool_recycle=3600, # Recycle after 1 hour connect_args={ "server_settings": {"application_name": "worker"}, "command_timeout": 60, } )

h1. Current: Single process with asyncio.run()

h1. Problem: No process supervision, crashes = downtime

Issues:

No automatic restart on crash No health monitoring Single point of failure Manual start/stop only *GCP Solutions:*

Use Cloud Run Jobs for serverless workers (auto-scaling, auto-restart) Use GKE with Kubernetes Jobs/CronJobs for more control Use Compute Engine with systemd for traditional approach Consider Cloud Tasks instead of polling pattern
